sen.e: Tendai-zasu (head priest of the Tendai sect) is a post that serves as the resident priest of Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple, the head temple of the Tendai sect, exercising general supervision over all of its sub-temples.

sen.j: 2世円澄までは延暦寺内の私称であったが、3世の円仁からは太政官が官符をもって任命する公的な役職となり、明治4年（1871年）まで続いた。
sen.e: Up to the times of the second head priest Encho, the term Tendai-zasu was a private title used within a compound of Enryaku-ji Temple but, starting with the third head priest Ennin, it became an official post appointed by way of kanpu (official documents from Dajokan or Grand Council of State) issued by Dajokan (Grand Council of State) which continued until 1871.

sen.j: 1人で複数回任命されることも多く、慈円などは3度、尊円法親王などは4度、天台座主に就いている。
sen.e: There have been numerous occasions when the same person received the appointment more than once with, for example, Jien and Cloistered Imperial Prince Sonen assuming the post of Tendai-zasu 3 and 4 times, respectively.

sen.j: 中世になると、摂家門跡、宮門跡の制度が整えられ、とりわけ妙法院・青蓮院・三千院（天台三門跡）から法親王が、天台座主として就任することが多くなった。
sen.e: In the early Middle Ages, with the Sekke-monzeki (the priest clan eligible for regents) and miya-monzeki (temples headed by imperial princes) systems being in place, cloistered imperial princes from Myoho-in Temple, Joren-in Temple and Sanzen-in Temple (the Tendai Three Monzeki) in particular began to assume the position of Tendai-zasu frequently.

sen.j: 江戸時代になると、江戸幕府によって東国の天台宗の大寺院として日光の日光山輪王寺と上野の東叡山寛永寺（開山は天海）が建立されていた。
sen.e: In the Edo Period, as the grand temples of the Tendai sect in Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region), Nikko-zan Rinno-ji Temple in Nikko and Toeizan Kanei-ji Temple (Tenkai was the founder and the first chief priest) in Ueno were built by the Edo shogunate with Rinno-ji Temple being designated as a temple headed by imperial princes (referred to as Rinnojinomiya or Nikko-monzeki), whereby, since 1656, it was decided that Rinnojinomiya had double assignments as the resident priest of Toeizan and Tendai-zasu being responsible for general supervision of the three temples of the Tendai sect in the foregoing.

sen.j: 輪王寺は宮門跡とされ（輪王寺宮、日光門跡）、明暦2年（1656年）以降は、輪王寺宮が東叡山の門跡と天台座主を兼務し、以上の天台三山を総監することが定められた（三山管領宮）。
sen.e: Rinno-ji Temple was designated as a temple headed by imperial princes (referred to as Rinnojinomiya or Nikko-monzeki), and it was settled that after 1656 Rinnojinomiya had responsibilities both as the resident priest of Toeizan and Tendai-zasu, being responsible for general supervision of the three temples of the Tendai sect above.

sen.j: 明治4年（1871年）をもって、太政官による任命は廃止され、天台座主そのものも無くなったが、天台宗内外に復活を望む声は多く、明治17年（1885年）より、再び私称として復活した。
sen.e: In 1871 the designation of the Tendai-zasu was repealed by the Dajokan (Grand Council of State) and the position of Tendai-zasu disappeared, but following the many calls for its restoration both from within the Tendai sect and without, in 1885 it was revived in the form of a private title.
